      29             : /*
      30             :  * Moving GC Stack Rooting
      31             :  *
      32             :  * A moving GC may change the physical location of GC allocated things, even
      33             :  * when they are rooted, updating all pointers to the thing to refer to its new
      34             :  * location. The GC must therefore know about all live pointers to a thing,
      35             :  * not just one of them, in order to behave correctly.
      36             :  *
      37             :  * The |Rooted| and |Handle| classes below are used to root stack locations
      38             :  * whose value may be held live across a call that can trigger GC. For a
      39             :  * code fragment such as:
      40             :  *
      41             :  * JSObject* obj = NewObject(cx);
      42             :  * DoSomething(cx);
      43             :  * ... = obj->lastProperty();
      44             :  *
      45             :  * If |DoSomething()| can trigger a GC, the stack location of |obj| must be
      46             :  * rooted to ensure that the GC does not move the JSObject referred to by
      47             :  * |obj| without updating |obj|'s location itself. This rooting must happen
      48             :  * regardless of whether there are other roots which ensure that the object
      49             :  * itself will not be collected.
      50             :  *
      51             :  * If |DoSomething()| cannot trigger a GC, and the same holds for all other
      52             :  * calls made between |obj|'s definitions and its last uses, then no rooting
      53             :  * is required.
      54             :  *
      55             :  * SpiderMonkey can trigger a GC at almost any time and in ways that are not
      56             :  * always clear. For example, the following innocuous-looking actions can
      57             :  * cause a GC: allocation of any new GC thing; JSObject::hasProperty;
      58             :  * JS_ReportError and friends; and ToNumber, among many others. The following
      59             :  * dangerous-looking actions cannot trigger a GC: js_malloc, cx->malloc_,
      60             :  * rt->malloc_, and friends and JS_ReportOutOfMemory.
      61             :  *
      62             :  * The following family of three classes will exactly root a stack location.
      63             :  * Incorrect usage of these classes will result in a compile error in almost
      64             :  * all cases. Therefore, it is very hard to be incorrectly rooted if you use
      65             :  * these classes exclusively. These classes are all templated on the type T of
      66             :  * the value being rooted.
      67             :  *
      68             :  * - Rooted<T> declares a variable of type T, whose value is always rooted.
      69             :  *   Rooted<T> may be automatically coerced to a Handle<T>, below. Rooted<T>
      70             :  *   should be used whenever a local variable's value may be held live across a
      71             :  *   call which can trigger a GC.
      72             :  *
      73             :  * - Handle<T> is a const reference to a Rooted<T>. Functions which take GC
      74             :  *   things or values as arguments and need to root those arguments should
      75             :  *   generally use handles for those arguments and avoid any explicit rooting.
      76             :  *   This has two benefits. First, when several such functions call each other
      77             :  *   then redundant rooting of multiple copies of the GC thing can be avoided.
      78             :  *   Second, if the caller does not pass a rooted value a compile error will be
      79             :  *   generated, which is quicker and easier to fix than when relying on a
      80             :  *   separate rooting analysis.
      81             :  *
      82             :  * - MutableHandle<T> is a non-const reference to Rooted<T>. It is used in the
      83             :  *   same way as Handle<T> and includes a |set(const T& v)| method to allow
      84             :  *   updating the value of the referenced Rooted<T>. A MutableHandle<T> can be
      85             :  *   created with an implicit cast from a Rooted<T>*.
      86             :  *
      87             :  * In some cases the small performance overhead of exact rooting (measured to
      88             :  * be a few nanoseconds on desktop) is too much. In these cases, try the
      89             :  * following:
      90             :  *
      91             :  * - Move all Rooted<T> above inner loops: this allows you to re-use the root
      92             :  *   on each iteration of the loop.
      93             :  *
      94             :  * - Pass Handle<T> through your hot call stack to avoid re-rooting costs at
      95             :  *   every invocation.
      96             :  *
      97             :  * The following diagram explains the list of supported, implicit type
      98             :  * conversions between classes of this family:
      99             :  *
     100             :  *  Rooted<T> ----> Handle<T>
     101             :  *     |               ^
     102             :  *     |               |
     103             :  *     |               |
     104             :  *     +---> MutableHandle<T>
     105             :  *     (via &)
     106             :  *
     107             :  * All of these types have an implicit conversion to raw pointers.
     108             :  */
     109             : 
     110             : namespace js {
     111             : 
     112             : template <typename T>
     113             : struct BarrierMethods {
     114             : };
     115             : 
     116             : template <typename Element, typename Wrapper>

     162             :         set(p);                                                                                   \

     164             :     }                                                                                             \

     168             :     }                                                                                             \
     169             : 
     170             : #define DELETE_ASSIGNMENT_OPS(Wrapper, T)                                                         \
     171             :     template <typename S> Wrapper<T>& operator=(S) = delete;                                      \
     172             :     Wrapper<T>& operator=(const Wrapper<T>&) = delete;
     173             : 
     174             : #define DECLARE_NONPOINTER_ACCESSOR_METHODS(ptr)                                                  \
     175             :     const T* address() const { return &(ptr); }                                                   \
     176             :     const T& get() const { return (ptr); }                                                        \
     177             : 
     178             : #define DECLARE_NONPOINTER_MUTABLE_ACCESSOR_METHODS(ptr)                                          \
     179             :     T* address() { return &(ptr); }                                                               \
     180             :     T& get() { return (ptr); }                                                                    \
     181             : 
     182             : } /* namespace js */

     210             : /**
     211             :  * The Heap<T> class is a heap-stored reference to a JS GC thing. All members of
     212             :  * heap classes that refer to GC things should use Heap<T> (or possibly
     213             :  * TenuredHeap<T>, described below).
     214             :  *
     215             :  * Heap<T> is an abstraction that hides some of the complexity required to
     216             :  * maintain GC invariants for the contained reference. It uses operator
     217             :  * overloading to provide a normal pointer interface, but notifies the GC every
     218             :  * time the value it contains is updated. This is necessary for generational GC,
     219             :  * which keeps track of all pointers into the nursery.
     220             :  *
     221             :  * Heap<T> instances must be traced when their containing object is traced to
     222             :  * keep the pointed-to GC thing alive.
     223             :  *
     224             :  * Heap<T> objects should only be used on the heap. GC references stored on the
     225             :  * C/C++ stack must use Rooted/Handle/MutableHandle instead.
     226             :  *
     227             :  * Type T must be a public GC pointer type.
     228             :  */

     351             : /**
     352             :  * The TenuredHeap<T> class is similar to the Heap<T> class above in that it
     353             :  * encapsulates the GC concerns of an on-heap reference to a JS object. However,
     354             :  * it has two important differences:
     355             :  *
     356             :  *  1) Pointers which are statically known to only reference "tenured" objects
     357             :  *     can avoid the extra overhead of SpiderMonkey's write barriers.
     358             :  *
     359             :  *  2) Objects in the "tenured" heap have stronger alignment restrictions than
     360             :  *     those in the "nursery", so it is possible to store flags in the lower
     361             :  *     bits of pointers known to be tenured. TenuredHeap wraps a normal tagged
     362             :  *     pointer with a nice API for accessing the flag bits and adds various
     363             :  *     assertions to ensure that it is not mis-used.
     364             :  *
     365             :  * GC things are said to be "tenured" when they are located in the long-lived
     366             :  * heap: e.g. they have gained tenure as an object by surviving past at least
     367             :  * one GC. For performance, SpiderMonkey allocates some things which are known
     368             :  * to normally be long lived directly into the tenured generation; for example,
     369             :  * global objects. Additionally, SpiderMonkey does not visit individual objects
     370             :  * when deleting non-tenured objects, so object with finalizers are also always
     371             :  * tenured; for instance, this includes most DOM objects.
     372             :  *
     373             :  * The considerations to keep in mind when using a TenuredHeap<T> vs a normal
     374             :  * Heap<T> are:
     375             :  *
     376             :  *  - It is invalid for a TenuredHeap<T> to refer to a non-tenured thing.
     377             :  *  - It is however valid for a Heap<T> to refer to a tenured thing.
     378             :  *  - It is not possible to store flag bits in a Heap<T>.
     379             :  */
     380             : template <typename T>
     381             : class TenuredHeap : public js::HeapBase<T, TenuredHeap<T>>
     382             : {
     383             :   public:
     384             :     using ElementType = T;
     385             : 
     386        8206 :     TenuredHeap() : bits(0) {
     387             :         static_assert(sizeof(T) == sizeof(TenuredHeap<T>),
     388             :                       "TenuredHeap<T> must be binary compatible with T.");
     389             :     }
     390        8936 :     explicit TenuredHeap(T p) : bits(0) { setPtr(p); }
     391             :     explicit TenuredHeap(const TenuredHeap<T>& p) : bits(0) { setPtr(p.getPtr()); }
     392             : 
     393             :     void setPtr(T newPtr) {
     394             :         MOZ_ASSERT((reinterpret_cast<uintptr_t>(newPtr) & flagsMask) == 0);
     395             :         if (newPtr)
     396             :             AssertGCThingMustBeTenured(newPtr);
     397       17219 :         bits = (bits & flagsMask) | reinterpret_cast<uintptr_t>(newPtr);
     398             :     }
     399             : 
     400             :     void setFlags(uintptr_t flagsToSet) {
     401             :         MOZ_ASSERT((flagsToSet & ~flagsMask) == 0);

     451             :

     454             : 
     455             : /**
     456             :  * Reference to a T that has been rooted elsewhere. This is most useful
     457             :  * as a parameter type, which guarantees that the T lvalue is properly
     458             :  * rooted. See "Move GC Stack Rooting" above.
     459             :  *
     460             :  * If you want to add additional methods to Handle for a specific
     461             :  * specialization, define a HandleBase<T> specialization containing them.
     462             :  */
     463             : template <typename T>
     464             : class MOZ_NONHEAP_CLASS Handle : public js::HandleBase<T, Handle<T>>
     465             : {
     466             :     friend class JS::MutableHandle<T>;
     467             :

     470             :

     473      599615 :     MOZ_IMPLICIT Handle(Handle<S> handle,

     475             :     {

     479      599615 :     }

     483             :                       "nullptr_t overload not valid for non-pointer types");
     484             :         static void* const ConstNullValue = nullptr;
     485      454889 :         ptr = reinterpret_cast<const T*>(&ConstNullValue);
     486           0 :     }
     487             : 
     488        6772 :     MOZ_IMPLICIT Handle(MutableHandle<T> handle) {
     489      502561 :         ptr = handle.address();
     490        6772 :     }
     491             : 
     492             :     /*
     493             :      * Take care when calling this method!
     494             :      *
     495             :      * This creates a Handle from the raw location of a T.
     496             :      *
     497             :      * It should be called only if the following conditions hold:
     498             :      *
     499             :      *  1) the location of the T is guaranteed to be marked (for some reason
     500             :      *     other than being a Rooted), e.g., if it is guaranteed to be reachable
     501             :      *     from an implicit root.
     502             :      *
     503             :      *  2) the contents of the location are immutable, or at least cannot change
     504             :      *     for the lifetime of the handle, as its users may not expect its value

     659             : 
     660             : // Provide hash codes for Cell kinds that may be relocated and, thus, not have
     661             : // a stable address to use as the base for a hash code. Instead of the address,
     662             : // this hasher uses Cell::getUniqueId to provide exact matches and as a base
     663             : // for generating hash codes.
     664             : //
     665             : // Note: this hasher, like PointerHasher can "hash" a nullptr. While a nullptr
     666             : // would not likely be a useful key, there are some cases where being able to
     667             : // hash a nullptr is useful, either on purpose or because of bugs:
     668             : // (1) existence checks where the key may happen to be null and (2) some
     669             : // aggregate Lookup kinds embed a JSObject* that is frequently null and do not
     670             : // null test before dispatching to the hasher.
     671             : template <typename T>
     672             : struct JS_PUBLIC_API(MovableCellHasher)
     673             : {
     674             :     using Key = T;
     675             :     using Lookup = T;
     676             : 
     677             :     static bool hasHash(const Lookup& l);
     678             :     static bool ensureHash(const Lookup& l);
     679             :     static HashNumber hash(const Lookup& l);
     680             :     static bool match(const Key& k, const Lookup& l);
     681           0 :     static void rekey(Key& k, const Key& newKey) { k = newKey; }
     682             : };
     683             : 
     684             : template <typename T>
     685             : struct JS_PUBLIC_API(MovableCellHasher<JS::Heap<T>>)
     686             : {
     687             :     using Key = JS::Heap<T>;
     688             :     using Lookup = T;
     689             : 
     690        1600 :     static bool hasHash(const Lookup& l) { return MovableCellHasher<T>::hasHash(l); }
     691         265 :     static bool ensureHash(const Lookup& l) { return MovableCellHasher<T>::ensureHash(l); }
     692        1355 :     static HashNumber hash(const Lookup& l) { return MovableCellHasher<T>::hash(l); }
     693         325 :     static bool match(const Key& k, const Lookup& l) {
     694         325 :         return MovableCellHasher<T>::match(k.unbarrieredGet(), l);
     695             :     }
     696             :     static void rekey(Key& k, const Key& newKey) { k.unsafeSet(newKey); }
     697             : };
     698             :

    1055             : JS_PUBLIC_API(void)
    1056             : AddPersistentRoot(RootingContext* cx, RootKind kind, PersistentRooted<void*>* root);
    1057             : 
    1058             : /**
    1059             :  * A copyable, assignable global GC root type with arbitrary lifetime, an
    1060             :  * infallible constructor, and automatic unrooting on destruction.
    1061             :  *
    1062             :  * These roots can be used in heap-allocated data structures, so they are not
    1063             :  * associated with any particular JSContext or stack. They are registered with
    1064             :  * the JSRuntime itself, without locking, so they require a full JSContext to be
    1065             :  * initialized, not one of its more restricted superclasses. Initialization may
    1066             :  * take place on construction, or in two phases if the no-argument constructor
    1067             :  * is called followed by init().
    1068             :  *
    1069             :  * Note that you must not use an PersistentRooted in an object owned by a JS
    1070             :  * object:
    1071             :  *
    1072             :  * Whenever one object whose lifetime is decided by the GC refers to another
    1073             :  * such object, that edge must be traced only if the owning JS object is traced.
    1074             :  * This applies not only to JS objects (which obviously are managed by the GC)
    1075             :  * but also to C++ objects owned by JS objects.
    1076             :  *
    1077             :  * If you put a PersistentRooted in such a C++ object, that is almost certainly
    1078             :  * a leak. When a GC begins, the referent of the PersistentRooted is treated as
    1079             :  * live, unconditionally (because a PersistentRooted is a *root*), even if the
    1080             :  * JS object that owns it is unreachable. If there is any path from that
    1081             :  * referent back to the JS object, then the C++ object containing the
    1082             :  * PersistentRooted will not be destructed, and the whole blob of objects will
    1083             :  * not be freed, even if there are no references to them from the outside.
    1084             :  *
    1085             :  * In the context of Firefox, this is a severe restriction: almost everything in
    1086             :  * Firefox is owned by some JS object or another, so using PersistentRooted in
    1087             :  * such objects would introduce leaks. For these kinds of edges, Heap<T> or
    1088             :  * TenuredHeap<T> would be better types. It's up to the implementor of the type
    1089             :  * containing Heap<T> or TenuredHeap<T> members to make sure their referents get
    1090             :  * marked when the object itself is marked.
    1091             :  */
    1092             : template<typename T>
    1093        6605 : class PersistentRooted : public js::RootedBase<T, PersistentRooted<T>>,
    1094             :                          private mozilla::LinkedListElement<PersistentRooted<T>>
    1095             : {
    1096             :     using ListBase = mozilla::LinkedListElement<PersistentRooted<T>>;

    1309             : namespace js {
    1310             : namespace detail {
    1311             : 
    1312             : // DefineComparisonOps is a trait which selects which wrapper classes to define
    1313             : // operator== and operator!= for. It supplies a getter function to extract the
    1314             : // value to compare. This is used to avoid triggering the automatic read
    1315             : // barriers where appropriate.
    1316             : //
    1317             : // If DefineComparisonOps is not specialized for a particular wrapper you may
    1318             : // get errors such as 'invalid operands to binary expression' or 'no match for
    1319             : // operator==' when trying to compare against instances of the wrapper.
    1320             : 
    1321             : template <typename T>
    1322             : struct DefineComparisonOps : mozilla::FalseType {};
    1323             : 
    1324             : template <typename T>
    1325             : struct DefineComparisonOps<JS::Heap<T>> : mozilla::TrueType {
    1326             :     static const T& get(const JS::Heap<T>& v) { return v.unbarrieredGet(); }
    1327             : };
    1328             : 
    1329             : template <typename T>
    1330             : struct DefineComparisonOps<JS::TenuredHeap<T>> : mozilla::TrueType {
    1331             :     static const T get(const JS::TenuredHeap<T>& v) { return v.unbarrieredGetPtr(); }
    1332             : };
    1333             : 
    1334             : template <>
    1335             : struct DefineComparisonOps<JS::ObjectPtr> : mozilla::TrueType {
    1336             :     static const JSObject* get(const JS::ObjectPtr& v) { return v.unbarrieredGet(); }
    1337             : };
    1338             : 
    1339             : template <typename T>

    1372             : // Overload operator== and operator!= for all types with the DefineComparisonOps
    1373             : // trait using the supplied getter.
    1374             : //
    1375             : // There are four cases:
    1376             :
